<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 117, 378, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSEâ„¢  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 172, 181, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 195, 365, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 195, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
0625/22 February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 904, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 248, 505, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 278, 487, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 338, 226, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 354, 905, 520]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 548, 218, 561]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 564, 568, 610]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 549, 91]]<|/det|> 1 The diagram shows three forces acting on an object. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 101, 665, 183]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 656, 214]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the resultant force acting on the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 225, 144, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 225, 201, 240]]<|/det|> A 2.0 N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 225, 313, 240]]<|/det|> B <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 225, 363, 240]]<|/det|> 10 N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 225, 529, 240]]<|/det|> C 14 N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 225, 666, 240]]<|/det|> D 16 N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 269, 97, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 269, 443, 285]]<|/det|> 2 Which row defines speed and velocity? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 298, 760, 428]]<|/det|>
speedvelocity
Adistance travelled in a given directionspeed per unit time
Bdistance travelled per unit timespeed in a given direction
Cdistance travelled in a given directionspeed in a given direction
Ddistance travelled per unit timespeed per unit time
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 454, 97, 471]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 454, 504, 471]]<|/det|> 3 The graph shows the journey of a motorcyclist. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 484, 918, 515]]<|/det|> Which section of the graph shows the time when the motorcyclist is stationary at some traffic lights? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 526, 690, 680]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 359, 97, 376]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 359, 529, 376]]<|/det|> 5 The load-extension graph for a material is shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 390, 517, 407]]<|/det|> Which point indicates the limit of proportionality? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 418, 660, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 622, 97, 638]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 622, 752, 640]]<|/det|> 6 An object of mass 4.0 kg is moving with a velocity of 3.0 m/s in a straight line. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 653, 428, 669]]<|/det|> What is the momentum of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 682, 136, 698]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 682, 737, 698]]<|/det|> A \(0.75 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) B \(1.3 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) C \(12 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) D \(24 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 74, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
7 A tall cylinder is partly filled with two liquids, which do not mix. The two liquids have different densities. A student measures the pressure due to the liquids at different depths.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 114, 698, 278]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 288, 769, 306]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the liquid pressure varies between positions P and Q?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 314, 845, 625]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 650, 97, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 651, 670, 668]]<|/det|>
8 A tennis ball with momentum \(2.3 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) is struck by a tennis racket.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 681, 636, 698]]<|/det|>
The racket causes the direction of motion of the ball to reverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 712, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
The racket exerts an average force of 1500 N during the impact with the ball. The racket and ball are in contact with each other for a time of 0.0024 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 757, 789, 774]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the momentum of the ball as it leaves the tennis racket?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 808, 144, 825]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 787, 744, 804]]<|/det|>
A 1.3kgm/s B 3.6kgm/s C 5.9kgm/s D 8.6kgm/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 74, 447, 91]]<|/det|> 9 A car is travelling at a speed of 8.0 m/s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 504, 120]]<|/det|> The kinetic energy stored in the car is 32 000 J . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 777, 150]]<|/det|> What is the kinetic energy stored in the car when its speed increases to 16 m/s? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 163, 144, 179]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 163, 735, 179]]<|/det|> A 16 000 J B 32 000 J C 64 000 J D 130 000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 208, 116, 224]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 208, 650, 224]]<|/det|> 10 The Sun is not the primary source of energy for which resource? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 236, 144, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 235, 190, 252]]<|/det|> A oil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 262, 144, 278]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 262, 193, 278]]<|/det|> B tidal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 288, 144, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 288, 200, 304]]<|/det|> C wind <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 315, 201, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 314, 201, 330]]<|/det|> D wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 359, 116, 376]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 358, 920, 390]]<|/det|> 11 An experiment is done to compare the rate of conduction of thermal energy in metal and plastic spoons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 402, 804, 419]]<|/det|> An ice cube is placed on one end of each spoon and the other end is heated gently. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 429, 818, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 534, 628, 551]]<|/det|> Which row has the correct prediction and correct explanation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 562, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
predictionexplanation
AThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the metal spoon.Metal is a good conductor.
BThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the metal spoon.Plastic is a good conductor.
CThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the plastic spoon.Metal is a poor conductor.
DThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the plastic spoon.Plastic is a poor conductor.
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 720, 116, 736]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 720, 920, 751]]<|/det|> 12 Four students determine the efficiency of four different electrical devices. The teacher knows that one student has made a mistake in the calculation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 765, 457, 781]]<|/det|> Which value for efficiency is not correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 794, 144, 810]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 792, 195, 810]]<|/det|> A 12% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 794, 361, 810]]<|/det|> B 36% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 794, 527, 810]]<|/det|> C 78% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 794, 703, 810]]<|/det|> D 102%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 116, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 616, 91]]<|/det|>
13 A sample of gas is sealed inside a container of fixed volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 452, 120]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the gas is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 660, 151]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why the pressure of the gas increases?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 163, 144, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 161, 740, 179]]<|/det|>
A The gas particles collide with the walls of the container more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 189, 144, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 188, 486, 205]]<|/det|>
B The mass of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 215, 144, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 214, 606, 231]]<|/det|>
C The number of gas particles in the container increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 240, 636, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 240, 633, 256]]<|/det|>
D The time between collisions of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 285, 116, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 284, 826, 301]]<|/det|>
14 A student does an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 314, 462, 330]]<|/det|>
She records the following measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 344, 388, 361]]<|/det|>
energy supplied \(=12 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 370, 405, 386]]<|/det|>
initial temperature \(=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 396, 398, 412]]<|/det|>
final temperature \(=45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 422, 421, 438]]<|/det|>
mass of metal block \(=600 \mathrm{~g}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 451, 555, 468]]<|/det|>
What is the specific heat capacity of the metal block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 480, 144, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 479, 316, 496]]<|/det|>
A \(8.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~}^{\circ} \mathrm{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 505, 147, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 504, 272, 521]]<|/det|>
B \(0.80 \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~}^{\circ} \mathrm{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 530, 144, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 530, 266, 546]]<|/det|>
C \(180 \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~}^{\circ} \mathrm{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 556, 144, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 556, 266, 573]]<|/det|>
D \(800 \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~}^{\circ} \mathrm{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 602, 116, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 600, 920, 633]]<|/det|>
15 A metal block is left overnight in a cool, shady room. In the morning, the metal block is moved into warm surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 647, 653, 663]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the metal block is correct in the morning?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 675, 144, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 674, 555, 691]]<|/det|>
A The internal energy of the metal block increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 701, 144, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 700, 539, 717]]<|/det|>
B The temperature of the metal block decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 727, 144, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 727, 615, 744]]<|/det|>
C Convection transfers energy throughout the metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 753, 144, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 753, 386, 770]]<|/det|>
D The metal contracts slightly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 798, 116, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 797, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
16 A fixed mass of gas is contained within a sealed syringe at a pressure of \(100 \mathrm{kPa}\). The plunger is slowly moved until the pressure is \(80 \mathrm{kPa}\). The final volume of the gas is \(50 \mathrm{cm}^{3}\). The temperature of the gas does **not** change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 858, 610, 875]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the gas before the plunger is moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 885, 144, 902]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 884, 230, 902]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 885, 380, 902]]<|/det|>
B \(40 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 885, 546, 902]]<|/det|>
C \(63 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 885, 724, 902]]<|/det|>
D \(160 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 116, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 76, 918, 107]]<|/det|> 17 The diagram shows the more energetic water molecules escaping from the surface of liquid water. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[314, 116, 685, 234]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 247, 452, 262]]<|/det|> What is this process called? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 275, 144, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 274, 295, 290]]<|/det|> A Brownian motion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 301, 148, 316]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 300, 280, 315]]<|/det|> B condensation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 327, 144, 343]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 326, 260, 341]]<|/det|> C evaporation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 352, 247, 367]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 351, 247, 366]]<|/det|> D conduction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 396, 116, 413]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 396, 416, 412]]<|/det|> 18 A hot object emits thermal radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 427, 814, 443]]<|/det|> Which row describes two changes that both reduce the rate of emission of radiation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 456, 568, 585]]<|/det|>
surface areasurface temperature
Aincreasedincreased
Bincreasedreduced
Creducedincreased
Dreducedreduced
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 612, 116, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 612, 760, 628]]<|/det|> 19 The frequency of a wave is doubled. The speed of the wave does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 643, 500, 658]]<|/det|> What happens to the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 670, 144, 686]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 670, 410, 686]]<|/det|> A It becomes four times as large. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 696, 316, 711]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 696, 317, 712]]<|/det|> B It does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 722, 144, 738]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 722, 243, 738]]<|/det|> C It doubles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 749, 131, 765]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 749, 231, 764]]<|/det|> D It halves. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 793, 116, 809]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 793, 494, 808]]<|/det|> 20 Which statement about ultrasound is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 821, 144, 837]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 820, 757, 836]]<|/det|> A It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 847, 144, 863]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 846, 750, 862]]<|/det|> B It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 873, 144, 889]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 872, 750, 888]]<|/det|> C It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 898, 144, 914]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 898, 744, 913]]<|/det|> D It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 746, 91]]<|/det|>
21 Which statement about the image produced by a plane mirror is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 102, 144, 118]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 102, 303, 118]]<|/det|>
A The image is real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 128, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 127, 329, 144]]<|/det|>
B The image is upright.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 153, 144, 169]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 153, 497, 169]]<|/det|>
C The image is the same size as the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 179, 144, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 179, 920, 211]]<|/det|>
D The distance from the image to the mirror is the same as the distance from the object to the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 240, 114, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 240, 626, 256]]<|/det|>
22 A ray of light is incident on a boundary between air and water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 269, 672, 286]]<|/det|>
Under which conditions is the ray of light totally internally reflected?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 298, 144, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 297, 890, 314]]<|/det|>
A The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air-water boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 324, 144, 340]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 323, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
B The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air-water boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 365, 144, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 364, 913, 380]]<|/det|>
C The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water-air boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 390, 144, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 389, 920, 421]]<|/det|>
D The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water-air boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 450, 114, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 450, 591, 466]]<|/det|>
23 A converging lens is used to make an image on a screen.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 477, 700, 625]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 640, 497, 656]]<|/det|>
Which type of image is formed on the screen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 668, 144, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 667, 295, 683]]<|/det|>
A real and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 694, 144, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 693, 287, 709]]<|/det|>
B real and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 719, 314, 735]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 719, 314, 735]]<|/det|>
C virtual and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 745, 304, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 745, 304, 761]]<|/det|>
D virtual and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
24 A negatively charged rod is brought near to a metal sphere. A positive charge develops on the surface of the metal sphere closest to the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 119, 222, 135]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 147, 144, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 146, 707, 164]]<|/det|>
A Electrons in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 174, 144, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 172, 700, 190]]<|/det|>
B Electrons in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 200, 144, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 198, 765, 216]]<|/det|>
C Positive charges in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 225, 144, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 223, 759, 240]]<|/det|>
D Positive charges in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 269, 114, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 268, 769, 286]]<|/det|>
25 The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell is defined in terms of which quantities?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 298, 144, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 297, 724, 314]]<|/det|>
A the energy transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 324, 144, 340]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 323, 724, 340]]<|/det|>
B the energy transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 350, 144, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 348, 715, 365]]<|/det|>
C the power transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 375, 144, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 374, 717, 392]]<|/det|>
D the power transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 420, 114, 436]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 419, 802, 437]]<|/det|>
26 A resistor of resistance \(R\) is connected to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 451, 400, 467]]<|/det|>
There is a current \(I\) in the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 481, 422, 497]]<|/det|>
Power \(P\) is dissipated by the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 511, 421, 527]]<|/det|>
In time \(t\), the energy transferred is \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 541, 358, 557]]<|/det|>
Which expression is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 567, 140, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 567, 710, 592]]<|/det|>
A \(E=I V t\) B \(E=P I t\) C \(P=V I R\) D \(P=\frac{V}{R}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 630, 114, 646]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 628, 798, 645]]<|/det|>
27 A copper wire of length 80 cm and cross-sectional area \(0.20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}\) has resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 658, 777, 675]]<|/det|>
Which length of copper wire of cross-sectional area \(0.40 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}\) has resistance \(R\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 688, 144, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 687, 757, 704]]<|/det|>
A \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\) B \(20 \mathrm{~cm}\) C \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\) D \(160 \mathrm{~cm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 75, 114, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 76, 907, 94]]<|/det|>
28 Four identical resistors are connected to a battery as shown. Each resistor has a value of \(120 \Omega\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 102, 613, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 316, 316, 333]]<|/det|>
Resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{4}\) is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 345, 831, 363]]<|/det|>
Which effect does removing this resistor have on the effective resistance of the circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 374, 144, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 373, 504, 390]]<|/det|>
A The effective resistance does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 400, 144, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 400, 515, 416]]<|/det|>
B The effective resistance decreases by \(20 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 427, 144, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 427, 507, 444]]<|/det|>
C The effective resistance increases by \(20 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 454, 144, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 454, 526, 471]]<|/det|>
D The effective resistance decreases by \(120 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 500, 90]]<|/det|> 29 The resistors in the circuit shown are identical. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 420, 120]]<|/det|> The reading on voltmeter \(V_{2}\) is 1.5 V . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 426, 150]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{2}\) is 0.50 A . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 426, 180]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{3}\) is 0.25 A . <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 193, 663, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 448, 583, 463]]<|/det|> What are the readings on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{1}\) and voltmeter \(V_{1}\) ? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 476, 504, 603]]<|/det|>
ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{1} / \mathrm{A}\)voltmeter \(V_{1} / V\)
A0.251.5
B0.253.0
C0.751.5
D0.753.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 114, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 621, 91]]<|/det|>
30 A wire is moved in the region between the poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 102, 645, 227]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 380, 259]]<|/det|>
A current is induced in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 273, 423, 289]]<|/det|>
In which direction is the wire moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 301, 144, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 300, 492, 317]]<|/det|>
A horizontally from the N pole to the S pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 327, 144, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 325, 492, 343]]<|/det|>
B horizontally from the S pole to the N pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 352, 144, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 350, 504, 368]]<|/det|>
C perpendicularly into the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 378, 144, 394]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 377, 520, 394]]<|/det|>
D perpendicularly out of the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 422, 114, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 422, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
31 A fixed resistor is connected to the secondary coil of a step-down transformer. The transformer is 100% efficient.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 464, 725, 605]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 618, 875, 635]]<|/det|>
The variable resistor is adjusted so that the current in the fixed resistor decreases by 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 648, 574, 665]]<|/det|>
What is the change to the current in the primary circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 675, 144, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 675, 343, 692]]<|/det|>
A It decreases by 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 702, 144, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 701, 422, 718]]<|/det|>
B It decreases by less than 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 728, 144, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 727, 432, 744]]<|/det|>
C It decreases by more than 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 754, 144, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 753, 320, 770]]<|/det|>
D There is no change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 857, 91]]<|/det|> 32 An electrical device changes the voltage of an electrical supply from 240 V a.c. to 20 V a.c. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 286, 119]]<|/det|> What is this device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 133, 144, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 133, 253, 148]]<|/det|> A generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 160, 214, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 159, 214, 174]]<|/det|> B a relay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 185, 148, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 184, 268, 199]]<|/det|> C a transformer <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 211, 148, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 210, 250, 225]]<|/det|> D a voltmeter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 255, 114, 271]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 255, 920, 300]]<|/det|> 33 An a.c. generator is set up so that its coil of wire is perpendicular to the magnetic field. The coil of wire is rotated slowly to produce an alternating electromotive force (e.m.f.). A graph of the induced e.m.f. against time is plotted as the coil rotates. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 312, 744, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 452, 740, 469]]<|/det|> Which section of the graph represents a rotation of three-quarters of a turn? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 481, 134, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 481, 185, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 481, 354, 497]]<|/det|> B OQ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 481, 520, 497]]<|/det|> C OR <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[618, 481, 685, 497]]<|/det|> D OS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 530, 114, 546]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 529, 920, 565]]<|/det|> 34 A uranium nucleus \(^{238}{ }_{92} \mathrm{U}\) decays to form thorium by emitting an \(\alpha\)-particle. Thorium decays to protactinium by emitting a \(\beta\)-particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 580, 824, 596]]<|/det|> Which row gives the atomic number and mass number of this isotope of protactinium? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 610, 484, 738]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 322, 114, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 322, 921, 355]]<|/det|> 36 Which precaution does not always reduce a scientist's exposure when working with sources of ionising radiation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 365, 826, 383]]<|/det|> A ensuring the scientist only works with sources of radiation that have long half-lives <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 392, 747, 409]]<|/det|> B increasing the distance between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 418, 727, 435]]<|/det|> C limiting the time for which the scientist handles the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 444, 727, 460]]<|/det|> D placing a lead shield between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 488, 114, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 488, 868, 504]]<|/det|> 37 A detector is placed near a radioactive isotope and records a count rate of 700 counts/ min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 518, 406, 535]]<|/det|> The half-life of the isotope is 8 min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 549, 564, 566]]<|/det|> The average background count rate is 60 counts/ min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 579, 627, 596]]<|/det|> What is the count rate measured by the detector after 16 min? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 607, 289, 623]]<|/det|> A 100 counts/ min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 633, 289, 648]]<|/det|> B 160 counts/ min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 658, 289, 673]]<|/det|> C 175 counts/ min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 684, 289, 699]]<|/det|> D 220 counts/ min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 920, 106]]<|/det|> 38 The nucleus of an isotope of nitrogen, N, absorbs a neutron. It then decays into an isotope of carbon, C, and emits x. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 119, 598, 140]]<|/det|> \[ { }_{0}^{1} \mathrm{~n} + { }_{7}^{14} \mathrm{~N} \rightarrow{ }_{6}^{14} \mathrm{C} + \mathrm{x} \] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 155, 207, 171]]<|/det|> What is x? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 185, 133, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 185, 235, 200]]<|/det|> A \(\alpha\) -particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 212, 133, 228]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 212, 235, 227]]<|/det|> B \(\beta\) -particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 238, 141, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 238, 242, 253]]<|/det|> C \(\gamma\) -radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 264, 141, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 264, 210, 279]]<|/det|> D proton <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 310, 107, 326]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 308, 920, 339]]<|/det|> 39 The graph shows how the strength of the Earth's gravitational field varies as the distance from the Earth's surface increases. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 350, 685, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 560, 920, 591]]<|/det|> Which row describes the effect that this has on the mass and on the weight of an object as it moves further away from the Earth's surface? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 604, 510, 732]]<|/det|>
mass of objectweight of object
Adecreasesdecreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 75, 116, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
40 A student plots a graph of the speed of different galaxies moving away from the Earth against their distance from the Earth.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 116, 860, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 373, 880, 390]]<|/det|>
Using the best straight line shown on the graph, what is the value of the Hubble constant \(H_{0}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 400, 144, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 400, 269, 416]]<|/det|>
A \(2.0 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 427, 144, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 427, 269, 444]]<|/det|>
B \(2.2 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 454, 144, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 454, 250, 470]]<|/det|>
C \(4.5 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 481, 144, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 481, 250, 497]]<|/det|>
D \(5.0 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~s}\)
